Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside decorated with seated lion on neb-basket sign, with sun-disc above back; motif stamped rather than incised; pierced through diameter; thick glaze with greenish turquoise tinge on surface; pale yellow core; surface rather damaged.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Curator's comments: Scarabs and scaraboids with a lion motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions, with the specific motif displayed on this scaraboid being found on several examples and notably in the Scarab Factory (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 34-45, see especially 44 for this piece). This scaraboid belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 95-96, type XXVIII A, subtype A72a). It should correspond to Gorton A184, though this number is used for two different scaraboids, this one which is decorated with a seated lion and another one decorated with a seated winged griffin (BM 1886,0401.1698). For a similar scaraboid: Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H3807. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 44)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 100, Type XXVIII A184) (problem with numbering)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.004) (phase 3)
